title: 111_hr6309
content: The Act may be cited as the "Notification of Origin of Telecommunications and Internet Consumer Exchanges Act of 2010" or the "NOTICE Act of 2010". Definitions are provided in Section 2. The Act defines key terms such as "business entity" as any organization established for profit through commerce in the US, "commerce" as defined in the Consumer Product Safety Act, and "consumer" as an individual purchasing goods or services for personal use within the US. The curr_chunk defines terms related to telecommunications, including "customer service communication," "telecommunication," and "wire communication." These terms are crucial for understanding communication between consumers and businesses. The curr_chunk defines the wire, cable, or other connection for transmission of communications, including all facilities and services related to such transmission. Business entities engaged in customer service communications must disclose their physical location. Business entities must require employees to disclose their physical location at the beginning of customer service communications, with exceptions for US-based businesses and communications initiated by consumers to foreign entities. Employees or agents of a business entity in customer service communications with consumers are exempt from location disclosure requirements if the communication was initiated by the consumer, the employee is outside the US, and the consumer is aware of this. Emergency service communications are also excluded. The Federal Trade Commission can exclude certain businesses or customer service communications from specific requirements if exceptionally compelling circumstances are found. Each year, businesses involved in customer service must certify compliance to the FTC. The FTC must establish necessary regulations within a year of the Act's enactment. The requirements apply to customer service communications from a certain date onwards. Customer service communications must comply with regulations starting one year after the Act's enactment. SEC. 4. ENFORCEMENT. Any failure to comply with section 3 of the Act will be treated as a violation of FTC regulations on unfair or deceptive acts. The FTC has the power to prevent violations of the Act and impose penalties on those who violate its regulations. The Act grants privileges and immunities under the Federal Trade Commission Act, preserving the authority of the FTC under other laws.
